h3. Summary
Pages created using the _Create from Template_ button don't inherit labels from the template, if the page with the button includes other macros.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a template including a label. 
# Create or edit a page and insert the _Create from Template_ in it, pointing to the template with a label.
# Insert *Section Macro* on the same page and save the page.
# In the page view, use the _Create from Template_ macro to create to a new page.

h3. Expected Results
# The new page, once saved, has the label(s) set in the template. 

h3. Actual Results
The label is not set for the new page.

h3.Workaround
- Remove other macros from the page that includes the _Create from Template_ macro.
- Use the *Create* button in the top navigation bar to create pages from templates.

At the moment, page watchers or owner will receive an email every time a task is checked/unchecked. This feature is good to notify any changes performed in a page.

However, for a page that's constantly used to track task status (frequent use of checking/unchecking task), the page watcher can receive huge number of emails every day.

The process of checking/unchecking task can be done without editing page, hence it's not possible to turn off the "notify watchers" functionality.

It would be useful to have the ability to switch off email notification for checking/unchecking task in a page to avoid email spam to the user.

h3.Workaround
Disable the {{tasks-notification}} module in the *Confluence Inline Tasks* add-on in {{Confluence Admin >> Manage Add-ons}}. But note that this is not recommended as there may be side effects to this (possible dependency from other plugins).

fields.description:
h3. to reproduce:
* go to {{/admin/viewcustomhtml.action}} (the three textareas are disabled as expected)
* click edit
* click cancel

h3. Expected:
The three text areas should be disabled 

h3. Result:
The three text areas are *not* disabled.

Furthermore, pressing "edit" again after that will submit the non-disabled text areas, triggering the XSS-Prevention in Chrome, which will just show an empty page afterwards. Going directly to {{/admin/editcustomhtml.action}} works as expected.

Scroll down for a workaround.

h3. Reason

The reason is that {{admin/lookandfeel/viewcustomhtml.vm}} and {{admin/lookandfeel/editcustomhtml.vm}} both define the same macro {{customHtmlInput}}, but with different bodies:

{{admin/lookandfeel/viewcustomhtml.vm}}: {code}#macro(customHtmlInput $id $labelText)
<textarea rows="4" id="${id}" name="${id}" class="textarea max-textarea" disabled="disabled">#if(${labelText} != "")${labelText}#else$action.getText("customhtml.not.configured")#end</textarea>
#end
{code}
{{admin/lookandfeel/editcustomhtml.vm}}: {code}#macro(customHtmlInput $id $labelText)
    <textarea rows="4" id="${id}" name="${id}" class="textarea max-textarea">${labelText}</textarea>
#end{code}

The problems with this is that [macros in velocity are global by default|http://wiki.apache.org/velocity/MacroIssues]:
{quote}
Macros can be stored either at a global level or on a per-template level. This is controlled by the config key "velocimacro.permissions.allow.inline.local.scope", which is false by default. (i.e. all macros are part of global scope).
{quote}

And this setting is not enabled in confluence, see  {{WEB-INF/classes/velocity.properties}}:
{code}
#velocimacro.permissions.allow.inline.local.scope = false
{code}
("#" is a comment character here)

So whoever defines that macro *last* wins, in the above case it is the definition from {{admin/lookandfeel/editcustomhtml.vm}}.

h3. Workaround:
Edit {{CONFLUENCE_INSTALL_DIR/confluence/admin/lookandfeel/viewcustomhtml.vm}} and rename all occurences of {{customHtmlInput}}, e.g. to {{customHtmlInputReadOnly}}. This can be done while the system is running.

h3. More problematic macros
It seems that customHtmlInput is not the only macro with this problem. On the confluence source, do:
{code}
$ find . -name "*.vm" | xargs grep '#macro' | grep -v "/target/" | awk -F'(' '{print $2}' | awk '{print $1}' | sort | uniq -c | grep -v "^ *1 "
   2 customHtmlInput
   2 errorBlock
   2 hierarchy
   2 iconSpan
   2 putMetadata
{code}

h3. Fun
Here is a picture of Dijkstra for you:
!dijkstra.jpg!
and a link to [GlobalVariablesConsideredHarmful|http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?GlobalVariablesConsideredHarmful]. I hope that I will someday get a prize for nice bugreports like this one..
fields.summary: Custom HTML breaks after first edit because of redefinition of velocity macro

The explain plan shows that to execute this query it’s scanning the attachments table and then for each row of the attachments table it’s scanning it again.
That is doing 283,170 x 283,170 row scans which is 80,185,248,900 rows for each attachment query.

If you’re doing this for each attachment that’s going to take ~ 1 second x 283,170 rows which is a long time.

{noformat}

  KEY `att_prevver_idx` (`PREVVER`),

  KEY `FK_ATTACHMENTS_CREATOR` (`CREATOR`),

  CONSTRAINT `FK54475F908C38FBEA` FOREIGN KEY (`PAGEID`) REFERENCES `content` (`CONTENTID`),
  CONSTRAINT `FK_ATTACHMENTS_CREATOR` FOREIGN KEY (`CREATOR`) REFERENCES `user_mapping` (`user_key`),
  CONSTRAINT `FK_ATTACHMENTS_LASTMODIFIER` FOREIGN KEY (`LASTMODIFIER`) REFERENCES `user_mapping` (`user_key`),

So it looks like this table is perhaps not indexed in a way which makes it easy to find the data that’s being looked for.
The table structure seems to have the same same issue.

Joining the data in a single query forces MySQL to combine things in a way which is not very efficient. It might be better to do some of these queries separately as they will be PK or index lookups and given the results adapt the remaining query that needs to be done.  This seems slower but if each individual query takes say 1ms then you get a gain of 1500x compared to the current behaviour.

h3. Summary
Restricted blog posts are not listed in the Restricted Pages list and cannot be seen by Confluence Administrators. This is against the description in the documentation, 
* [Viewing Restricted Pages|https://confluence.atlassian.com/conf51/viewing-restricted-pages-336169161.html]

The Confluence admin is not able to view the blog post as well from the space blog post stream page

Space Administrator should be able to view the list of restricted pages in a space

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new space
# Create a blog in this space
# Restrict this blog post to yourself
# Log in as Confluence Administrator user
# Go to the space > Space Tools > Permissions > Restricted Pages
# Access the blog post streams for the space with the Confluence admin account. Admin will not be able to view the blog post.

h3. Expected Results
# All the restricted pages are displayed in the list

h3. Actual Results
The blog post is not listed there and admin is not able to view the blog post as well
 
h3. Notes
Any restricted normal pages will be listed there

Comment from customer:
{quote}
On restricted pages the space/confluence admin is able to display the restricted pages in space administration -> permissions -> restricted pages
This is not possible for blog posts.
Our internal controlling MUST be able to at least be aware that there are blog posts not visible to them. This is not possible by now (5.7.3)
{quote}


h3. Workaround
1. Use the following SQL query to find out any blog post that has a "View" restriction set in the space level:
{code}
SELECT
s.SPACENAME,
s.SPACEID,
c.CONTENTID,
c.CONTENTTYPE,
c.TITLE,
o.CONT_PERM_TYPE

FROM
SPACES s
LEFT JOIN CONTENT c

ON
s.SPACEID = c.SPACEID
LEFT JOIN CONTENT_PERM_SET o

ON
c.CONTENTID = o.CONTENT_ID
WHERE c.CONTENTTYPE = 'BLOGPOST'
AND CONT_PERM_TYPE = 'View'
AND s.SPACENAME = '<name of space>'
ORDER BY 2 DESC, 1 ASC;
{code}

Take note of the "contentID" shown in the SQL result. Using Admin rights, access this page by its URL:

{code}
<base_URL>/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=<contentID obtained>
{code}

2. Disable normal users to restrict all contents in the space level:
Go to Space Tools > Permission > Remove the "Add/Delete" Restriction rights from normal users

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-37251].
  {panel}

h4. Problem
Supporting Confluence requires access to various information. Thread dumps, GC logs, SQL logging, access logging, etc. Confluence has very minimal logging enabled by default (out of that list only GC logging is enabled by default), and for good reason as log files would greatly increase their included content if all logging options were enabled (as most logging is done in atlassian-confluence.log). Some logging, for example SQL logging, is useless unless configuration files are change and Confluence is restarted (which is a huge inconvenience)

Further, to gather these logs requires generating a support zip through the Support Tools Plugin in the Confluence admin console (which does not always include the additional GC logging). This process is impossible to perform if Confluence cannot start, and makes gathering necessary information (i.e. configuration files in addition to logs) difficult for support and for the user.

h4. Proposed Solution
# Add the ability to create a support zip from the command line
** Accomplished via a script that gathers the same/similar information as a standard support zip
# Improve SQL logging when enabled from the UI
** Include trace logging to get the parameters being passed to the query
** Split this additional logging into its own .log file
# Fix (or remove) the thread dumps generated via the Confluence UI
** Currently Confluence does not generate full system thread dumps, and every time a thread dump is needed this article is linked: [Generating Thread Dumps Externally|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Generating+a+Thread+Dump+Externally]
** Either get the same information as an external thread dump or remove the feature entirely as it is not used by support
# Enable access logging by default and separate into its own .log file
** JIRA has this logging enabled by default

The April 2015 blog post for the latest update lists multiple security issues affecting server code, several exploitable over the network, and 3 that are severity 10.0 (their highest rating). They do not provide any details for us to know what these vulnerabilities are, aside from their CVE IDs. See https://blogs.oracle.com/security/entry/april_2015_critical_patch_update for all the details we have, and watch https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2015-0491 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2015-0459 and https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2015-0469 for publication.

We need to update the bundled version of the JRE to at least 1.7.0_79.

In versions of Confluence where we've dropped support for any JRE other than the one we bundle, we need to do this update as a matter of urgency.

We have a specific roadmap that when edited causes all connections to the server to begin timing out for that specific ip adddress. This includes connections via other browsers as well as over SSH (new and open). I've copied the exact same roadmap over to our test server and the same issue appears. Other roadmaps seem to work just fine and this one worked fine until it eventually got to this point. After about 10-15 minutes the connections open up again. Connections from other users or from other systems appear to work just fine. I also can not see anything in the system logs or the application logs that indicate an issue.

I attempted to use the source editor to get you a copy of the roadmap but it causes the same time out issue.
